summary: This is an email from Chris DiIonno forwarding a formal appeal regarding the denial of a covered action (2015-016/Knight Capital TCR & Appendix). The email alleges a miscarriage of justice in the sentencing of Dan Kamensky, claims a corrupt relationship between the SEC and Handler/Jefferies, and details multiple alleged frauds involving UBS, SEC LA, and various shell companies, accusing SEC officials of obstruction and protection of these frauds. This document is a lengthy email from whistleblower Christopher Dilorio to the SEC OWB, appealing the denial of his award claim for the Oppenheimer AML covered action (2015-016). He alleges the SEC used his information from his 2013 TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) to bring the Oppenheimer/Gibraltar complaint but obstructed a full investigation to protect entities like Knight/NITE, UBS, and Hanover/Magna. He details a complex web of alleged money laundering through penny stock shells, naked shorting, and SEC corruption, implicating numerous individuals and entities.

persons.name: Chris DiIonno
persons.context: Author of the email, making multiple allegations of fraud, corruption, and obstruction against the SEC, UBS, and other entities. Claims to be a whistleblower who was denied awards.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of a sentencing by Judge Cote which the author claims is a gross miscarriage of justice, allegedly set up by Handler/Ressler because his bid threatened their deal.

persons.name: Judge Cote
persons.context: The judge who sentenced Dan Kamensky. The author argues she should have declared a mistrial.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Mentioned as being in possession of information indicating a corrupt relationship between the SEC and Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Alleged to have a long-standing, grossly corrupt relationship with the SEC, along with Jefferies. Implicated in setting up Dan Kamensky.

persons.name: Ressler
persons.context: Co-founder of Ares Management, linked to Drexel with Handler. Allegedly set up Dan Kamensky with Handler to protect the value of the Neiman Marcus asset.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in 2019 for roles in microcap frauds; linked by Dilorio to Hanover/Magna and money laundering shells like NewLead and CGFIA.

persons.name: Tom Priore
persons.context: A known felon involved in an MI Acquisition with AQR and Sason, as mentioned in the author's claims.

persons.name: Norberg
persons.context: SEC Office of the Whistleblower official invoked the "Summary Disposition Rule" in denying an award for the UBS AML tip, which the author claims is illegal.

persons.name: Christopher J Dilorio
persons.context: The "Summary Disposition Rule" is referred to as the "Christopher J Dilorio rule" by the author, who claims it is illegally enacted.

persons.name: Searles
persons.context: SEC LA official accused of having zero jurisdiction, protecting UBS San Diego, and allowing multiple frauds and money laundering schemes to continue.

persons.name: Banerjee
persons.context: SEC LA official mentioned alongside Searles, accused of protecting frauds and being well-known to individuals running shell companies.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC Inspector General accused of clearly obstructing the author's complaint filed in 2015 regarding a denied award for a UBS Reg Sho complaint.

persons.name: Mckessy
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Norberg and Hoecker as part of the "criminal obstruction" that led to UBS cross-border business continuing.

persons.name: Jason Sunstein
persons.context: San Diego resident identified as CFO of several SEC-reporting money laundering shell companies trading on OTC Pinks, suggested to be known to SEC LA officials.

persons.name: Ashraf Rofail
persons.context: Identified as the CEO of Santeon Group (fka Air-Q), a company linked to African/Egyptian entities and individuals.

persons.name: Anton Chia
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to fraud and money laundering that SEC LA's Searles was involved with.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email and submitter of multiple TCRs to the SEC and FINRA alleging massive fraud, money laundering, and SEC obstruction related to Knight Capital/NITE, UBS, and penny stock shells.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: Recipient of the email; the SEC OWB chief who issued the preliminary denial of Dilorio's award claim.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Alleged operator of JMJ Financial, charged by the SEC in 2020 for unregistered penny stock dealing; linked by Dilorio to money laundering shells like IMDS and CGFIA.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.context: Formerly ran Equities at UBS; became CEO of KCG after the Getco reverse merger. Dilorio alleges he was involved in covering up illegal activity at Knight/NITE.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former head of the SEC Office of the Whistleblower; Dilorio corresponded with him and alleges McKessy solicited more information after receiving his TCR.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio had extensive correspondence in 2012 regarding penny stock shells CGFIA and AppTech.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: SEC IG whom Dilorio accuses of criminal obstruction for not interviewing him or informing Congress about his serious allegations.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: SEC Chair linked by Dilorio to Sullivan Cromwell and alleged conflicts of interest in facilitating the KCG/VIRT merger.

persons.name: Steven Peikin
persons.context: SEC Co-Director of Enforcement; Dilorio alleges he and Clayton should have recused themselves from NITE/VIRT matters due to conflicts.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Attorney at Sullivan Cromwell alleged to have advised Knight/KCG/VIRT on transactions facilitating fraud; linked to SEC Chair Clayton.

persons.name: David Della Sciucca Jr.
persons.context: Named in the SEC Gibraltar Securities complaint as a nominee involved with the Magnum d'Or shell.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: CEO of NETE, a company Dilorio alleges is a money laundering shell with numerous AML red flags.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Linked to Milken/Drexel and involved with Crede and Net Element, according to Dilorio's allegations.

persons.name: Michael Wachs
persons.context: Described as a felon and partner of Terren Peizer in Milken-related entities.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austrian/Israeli individual alleged to control Liechtenstein-based Alpha Capital Anstalt, linked to money laundering shells.

persons.name: Andrew Wimpfheimer
persons.role: Former NITE Trader, OTC Markets Board Member
persons.context: Former NITE trader and founding OTC Markets Board member, cited as part of the alleged corrupt system.

persons.name: Cromwell Coulson
persons.context: CEO of OTC Markets Group who chaired the FINRA Market Regulation Committee, implicated in the alleged system facilitating fraud.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.role: NITE Board Member, Trump Campaign Manager
persons.context: Sits on the NITE Board of Directors and was a Trump PA Campaign Manager; also linked to his own alleged money laundering shell FSD Parma.

persons.name: John McCarthy
persons.role: Former SEC NY Official, Knight/KCG Chief Counsel
persons.context: Former SEC NY official who ended up as Knight/KCG Chief Counsel; cited in the context of the Madoff scandal and alleged SEC obstruction.

persons.name: Vikas Arora
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016 regarding his TCR.

persons.name: Nathan Sarnacki
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016 regarding his TCR.

persons.name: Luis A. Aguilar
persons.context: Former SEC Commissioner who dissented in the Oppenheimer waiver, citing trading in "billions of shares of penny stocks."

persons.name: Kara M. Stein
persons.context: Former SEC Commissioner who dissented in the Oppenheimer waiver, citing trading in "billions of shares of penny stocks."

persons.name: Marc P. Berger
persons.context: SEC attorney named on the Sason/Magna complaint; his name appears on a document header.

persons.name: Hester Peirce
persons.context: SEC Commissioner congratulated by Dilorio on her nomination and referenced for her paper on FINRA lack of accountability.

connections.description: Allegedly set up Dan Kamensky together because his successful bid for Neiman Marcus would have devalued an asset and hurt Ares Management (co-founded by Ressler). Linked through Drexel.
Described as having a long-standing and grossly corrupt relationship with the SEC.
SEC LA officials mentioned together as protecting UBS San Diego and allowing multiple frauds to continue.
SEC officials (OWB and IG) accused together of criminal obstruction in handling the UBS whistleblower complaint.
Connected through an "MI Acquisition" deal, with Priore identified as a known felon.
The author suggests Sunstein, CFO of shell companies, is "no doubt well known" to Searles and Banerjee at SEC LA.
Dilorio is appealing the denial of his whistleblower award claim to SEC OWB Chief Norberg.
Dilorio corresponded with former OWB Chief McKessy, who allegedly solicited more information from him.
Dilorio had extensive 2012 correspondence with FINRA's Traxler about penny stock shells CGFIA and AppTech.
Alleged to be top traders in the same penny stock shells (CGFIA, IMDS, APCX) as part of a money laundering and naked shorting scheme.
Alleged symbiotic relationship where Hanover/Magna provided worthless certs and NITE executed trades/abusive naked shorting to convert them to real money.
Sason is linked to the Hanover/Magna entities alleged to be involved in microcap fraud and money laundering.
Keener operated the unregistered penny stock dealer JMJ Financial.
Coleman ran Equities at UBS during its Reg SHO and cross-border AML issues before becoming CEO of KCG.
Both worked at the law firm Sullivan Cromwell, which advised Knight/KCG/VIRT, creating alleged conflicts of interest.
Dilorio filed complaints with SEC IG Hoecker, accusing him of obstruction for not interviewing him or informing Congress.

events.title: Formal Appeal Email Sent
events.description: Chris DiIonno sends an email forwarding a formal appeal regarding the denial of covered action 2015-016/Knight Capital TCR & Appendix, containing wide-ranging allegations of corruption and fraud.

events.title: Ares Management Purchases Neiman Marcus
events.description: Ares Management, in a joint venture, purchased the luxury retailer Neiman Marcus. This deal is central to the allegation that Handler/Ressler set up Dan Kamensky.

events.title: Complaint Filed with SEC IG Hoecker
events.description: The author filed a complaint with SEC Inspector General Hoecker's office after receiving a denial for an award related to a UBS Reg Sho complaint, alleging obstruction.

events.title: DOJ Drops DPA with UBS
events.description: The Department of Justice dropped its Deferred Prosecution Agreement with UBS, under terms which allegedly required UBS's cross-border business to be shut downâ€”a requirement the author claims was never fulfilled.

events.title: International Land Alliance Inc. 8-K Filing
events.description: International Land Alliance Inc. filed an 8-K form with the SEC, noted by the author as part of the documentation for alleged shell companies.

events.title: Dilorio's First Whistleblower Complaint
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first whistleblower complaint with the SEC, detailing massive fraud centered on Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS (UBSS).

events.title: Knight Capital "Glitch"
events.description: A massive trading glitch at Knight Capital that led to a $460 million loss. Dilorio alleges this proved Knight was insolvent and triggered an SEC-orchestrated bailout.

events.title: Dilorio's Amended TCR Filed with Berger Montague
events.description: Dilorio submitted an amended TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) with law firm Berger Montague to the SEC, detailing allegations against Knight, UBS, and penny stock shells.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action (Covered Action 2015-016)
events.description: The SEC brought an administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for AML violations, which Dilorio claims was based on his information from the FINRA complaint.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC announced charges against Joshua Sason and others for roles in microcap frauds and unlawful offerings, which Dilorio claims was based on his earlier TCRs.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Justin W. Keener/JMJ Financial
events.description: The SEC charged Justin W. Keener d/b/a JMJ Financial as an unregistered penny stock dealer, which Dilorio claims was based on information he provided years earlier.

events.title: IRS CI Meeting with Dilorio
events.description: IRS CI Agents Vikas Arora and Nathan Sarnacki flew to Denver to meet with Dilorio regarding his TCR allegations.

events.title: DTCC Global Lock on CGFIA
events.description: The DTCC imposed a "Global Lock" on Colorado Goldfields Inc. (CGFIA) stock due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which Dilorio cites as clear evidence of naked shorting.

locations: Santa Monica, California (HQ of New Concepts shell)
Denver, Colorado (Where Dilorio met IRS agents and researched CGFIA)
Littleton, Colorado (Rented home of CGFIA CEO Guyer)
Neuchatel, Switzerland (Location connected to CGFIA CEO Guyer's previous endeavor)
The Woodlands, Texas (Office location for AppTech shell)
Boca Raton, Florida (Office location for AppTech shell)
Miami, Florida (Residence of Justin Keener and Oleg Firer)
Highlands Ranch, Colorado (Office connected to Antelope Technologies)
Nassau, Bahamas (Location of Gibraltar Global Securities)
keyFacts: The author alleges Judge Cote's sentencing of Dan Kamensky was a 'gross miscarriage of justice' and that Kamensky was set up by Handler and Ressler because his successful bid for Neiman Marcus would have harmed Ares Management's investment.
The document claims a 'long standing and grossly corrupt relationship' exists between the SEC and the financial firms Handler/Jefferies.

The author, a self-identified whistleblower, accuses SEC officials (Norberg, Mckessy, Hoecker) of 'criminal obstruction' for using an 'illegally enacted' rule to deny awards and for failing to shut down UBS's cross-border business after a 2010 DPA was dropped.

Multiple alleged frauds and shell companies (e.g., Viper Networks, Santeon Group, International Land Alliance) are detailed, with accusations that SEC LA officials (Searles, Banerjee) are protecting these operations and UBS San Diego.

The email serves as a formal appeal and compendium of allegations tying together separate cases (Kamensky, UBS, various shell companies) under a theme of systemic corruption and obstruction within the SEC and related courts.

The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges the SEC used his information from a 2013 TCR to bring the Oppenheimer/Gibraltar AML enforcement action but then obstructed a full investigation to protect major players like Knight Capital/NITE and UBS.

Dilorio claims Knight Capital (NITE) was insolvent as early as 2011 and that its core business was abusive naked shorting of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, a practice he says continues under Virtu Financial (VIRT).

A key piece of evidence cited is a 2013 CGFIA 10-Q filing that disclosed a DTCC "Global Lock" due to a third-party broker-dealer's actions, which Dilorio asserts is incontrovertible proof of naked shorting that the SEC ignored.

Dilorio alleges a deep network of connected individuals and entities involved in money laundering through penny stock shells, including figures linked to Michael Milken, such as Terren Peizer, and entities like Hanover/Magna, Alpha Capital Anstalt, and AQR blank check shells.

The document accuses the SEC Office of the Whistleblower and Inspector General Carl Hoecker of gross misconduct, including failing to properly distribute his information, denying his award on fabricated grounds, and obstructing congressional oversight.
